    Preliminary lmer models

    P. Melloy

    2020-03-10

    04_lmer.Rmd

    Aims

    Using the data collected from preliminary studies undertaken by Ihsan, we aim to produce a model when simulates the spread of conidia in a field within the season.

    if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, lme4, knitr, here)
    # import
lesion <- read_csv(here("inst/cache", "summarised_lesion_data.csv"))
weather <- read_csv(here("inst/cache", "weather_summary.csv"))

dat <- left_join(lesion, weather, by = c("site", "rep"))

    From this data we hope to obtain the following.

    • How far conidia can be dispersed in a spread event

    • What combination of wind speed / direction / rain effects the dispersal distance.

    Due to the lack of reps at some of the distances we will ignore transect as a factor. We know wind direction will influence our results and we will need to accept that adds variation for which we may not be able to account for statistically.

    I will start using lmer() to analyse the mean number of lesions per plant at each station. A station is defined by a pot containing five chickpea plants. The factor distance should be fit as a continuous variable, however because we don’t know if the relationship between mean lesions and distance from the conidia dispersal focus is linear, we will start with distance as a categorical variable.

    Site is a categorical variable explaining the trial location. Each site may have experienced a different number of spread events, defined by the term rep (replicate). Rainfall is required for conidia to disperse from the infected focus, and each replicate constitutes either an overhead irrigation event or a natural rainfall event. The following table describes the replicates per site and the summary weather data for that event.

    kable(weather, align = "c", caption = "Summary weather data for replicated rain event (rep) per unique site.")
    Summary weather data for replicated rain event (rep) per unique site.
    site rep mws ws_sd mwd sum_rain
    Curyo 1 3.577163 2.2302100 353.5045 0.8
    Horsham dryland 1 3.085387 1.9379332 311.0201 4.6
    Horsham dryland 2 3.996127 2.7133595 332.3283 18.6
    Horsham irrigated 1 1.902828 0.9050266 234.6542 0.0
    Horsham irrigated 2 2.233103 1.2895001 272.7072 0.0
    Horsham irrigated 3 6.531586 2.1241262 333.6699 0.6

    The first models I will look at are asking:

    1. What is the estimated mean lesions per plant as each distance from the focus, given that the conditions of each spread event is nested within each site.

    2. What is the estimated mean lesions per plant as each distance from the focus, given that the conditions of each spread event is nested within each site and the distance the spore travels is dependant on the spread event at each site.

    mod1 <-
  lmer(mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (1 | site / SpEv),
       data = dat)
cat("mod1")
    ## mod1
    formula(mod1)
    ## mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (1 | site/SpEv)
    mod2 <-
  lmer(mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) |
                                                 site / SpEv),
       data = dat)
cat("mod2")
    ## mod2
    formula(mod2)
    ## mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) | 
##     site/SpEv)
    # Compare models
anova(mod1, mod2)
    ## Data: dat
## Models:
## mod1: mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (1 | site/SpEv)
## mod2: mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) | 
## mod2:     site/SpEv)
##      Df    AIC    BIC  logLik deviance Chisq Chi Df Pr(>Chisq)    
## mod1  8 820.26 850.75 -402.13   804.26                            
## mod2 36 749.66 886.86 -338.83   677.66 126.6     28    1.7e-14 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

    A comparison of the two models shows us that mod2 is much better fit given the lower AIC.

    Lets examine the results of this analysis.

    summary(mod2)
    ## Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod']
## Formula: mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) |  
##     site/SpEv)
##    Data: dat
## 
## REML criterion at convergence: 687.9
## 
## Scaled residuals: 
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -5.2355 -0.5760 -0.0998  0.4332  4.4461 
## 
## Random effects:
##  Groups    Name                  Variance Std.Dev. Corr                   
##  SpEv:site (Intercept)           1.6676   1.2914                          
##            as.factor(distance)10 0.6135   0.7833   -1.00                  
##            as.factor(distance)25 1.5232   1.2342   -0.98  0.98            
##            as.factor(distance)50 1.4207   1.1920   -1.00  1.00  0.97      
##            as.factor(distance)75 1.7701   1.3304   -1.00  1.00  0.98  1.00
##  site      (Intercept)           0.6545   0.8090                          
##            as.factor(distance)10 0.2260   0.4754   -1.00                  
##            as.factor(distance)25 0.4022   0.6342   -1.00  1.00            
##            as.factor(distance)50 0.4201   0.6482   -1.00  1.00  1.00      
##            as.factor(distance)75 0.5879   0.7668   -1.00  1.00  1.00  1.00
##  Residual                        0.4101   0.6404                          
## Number of obs: 334, groups:  SpEv:site, 6; site, 3
## 
## Fixed effects:
##                       Estimate Std. Error t value
## (Intercept)             2.8256     0.7200   3.924
## as.factor(distance)10  -1.5259     0.4466  -3.417
## as.factor(distance)25  -1.9721     0.6390  -3.086
## as.factor(distance)50  -2.3827     0.6333  -3.762
## as.factor(distance)75  -2.5055     0.7202  -3.479
## 
## Correlation of Fixed Effects:
##             (Intr) a.()10 a.()25 a.()50
## as.fctr()10 -0.975                     
## as.fctr()25 -0.981  0.959              
## as.fctr()50 -0.988  0.966  0.971       
## as.fctr()75 -0.993  0.968  0.977  0.984
## convergence code: 0
## boundary (singular) fit: see ?isSingular

    This analysis shows there is little residual variance compared to the the variation explained by our random effects. Also we can see that the amount of variation explained by site is low.
    We should test that site is a significant random intercept. We can also note that as the distance increases so does the variance, this could be explained by the fact the spores are only going to travel farther on a bearing that is the same as the wind direction.

    # To test site we need to create a variable that describes a spread event regardless of location
mod3 <-
  lmer(mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) |
                                                 SpEv),
       data = dat)
cat("mod3")
    ## mod3
    formula(mod3)
    ## mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) | 
##     SpEv)
    # Compare models
anova(mod2, mod3)
    ## Data: dat
## Models:
## mod3: mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) | 
## mod3:     SpEv)
## mod2: mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) | 
## mod2:     site/SpEv)
##      Df    AIC    BIC  logLik deviance  Chisq Chi Df Pr(>Chisq)
## mod3 21 720.41 800.44 -339.20   678.41                         
## mod2 36 749.66 886.86 -338.83   677.66 0.7496     15          1

    Site is not a significant factor and we can use spread event variable instead. We will use mod3 in the following analysis. This is shown by the lower AIC for mod3 and that the site/SpEv nesting is not significant on the chi-squared test of models. We should check this is consistent for when distance is a continuous variable.

    # To test continous distance
mod4 <- lmer(mean_pot_count ~ distance + (distance | SpEv),
             data = dat)
cat("mod4")
    ## mod4
    formula(mod4)
    ## mean_pot_count ~ distance + (distance | SpEv)
    # Compare models
anova(mod3, mod4)
    ## Data: dat
## Models:
## mod4: mean_pot_count ~ distance + (distance | SpEv)
## mod3: mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) | 
## mod3:     SpEv)
##      Df    AIC    BIC  logLik deviance Chisq Chi Df Pr(>Chisq)    
## mod4  6 889.71 912.58 -438.85   877.71                            
## mod3 21 720.41 800.44 -339.20   678.41 199.3     15  < 2.2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

    mod 3 remains a better model compared to a model where distance is defined as continuous variable this probably relates to the non-linear relationship of distance and mean lesions per pot. For completeness lets test the nesting of site and SpEv when distance is continuous.

    # To test continous distance
mod5 <- lmer(mean_pot_count ~ distance + (distance | site / SpEv),
             data = dat)
    ## boundary (singular) fit: see ?isSingular
    cat("mod5")
    ## mod5
    formula(mod5)
    ## mean_pot_count ~ distance + (distance | site/SpEv)
    # Compare models
anova(mod4, mod5)
    ## refitting model(s) with ML (instead of REML)
    ## Data: dat
## Models:
## mod4: mean_pot_count ~ distance + (distance | SpEv)
## mod5: mean_pot_count ~ distance + (distance | site/SpEv)
##      Df    AIC    BIC  logLik deviance  Chisq Chi Df Pr(>Chisq)
## mod4  6 889.71 912.58 -438.85   877.71                         
## mod5  9 895.45 929.75 -438.72   877.45 0.2606      3     0.9673

    The model where site is not included remains the better model. Therefore we can conclude that site is not a contributing factor to the distance spores can travel.

    Finally I want to check the fit of the model when distance is fit as a ordered categorical variable, as we know it is. In the shape of the regression is tested against polynomials for non-linear terms.

    # To test continous distance
mod6 <-
  lmer(mean_pot_count ~ ordered(distance) + (ordered(distance) |
                                               SpEv),
       data = dat)
    ## boundary (singular) fit: see ?isSingular
    cat("mod6")
    ## mod6
    formula(mod6)
    ## mean_pot_count ~ ordered(distance) + (ordered(distance) | SpEv)
    # Compare models
anova(mod3, mod6)
    ## refitting model(s) with ML (instead of REML)
    ## Data: dat
## Models:
## mod3: mean_pot_count ~ as.factor(distance) + (as.factor(distance) | 
## mod3:     SpEv)
## mod6: mean_pot_count ~ ordered(distance) + (ordered(distance) | SpEv)
##      Df    AIC    BIC logLik deviance Chisq Chi Df Pr(>Chisq)    
## mod3 21 720.41 800.44 -339.2   678.41                            
## mod6 21 720.41 800.44 -339.2   678.41     0      0  < 2.2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

    This last test shows mod6 is a “better” model however the fit does not improve by much, because there is the same AIC. It also reinforces our suspicion that the relationship between number of lesions per pot and distance from the inoculumn focus is non-linear.

    summary(mod6)
    ## Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod']
## Formula: mean_pot_count ~ ordered(distance) + (ordered(distance) | SpEv)
##    Data: dat
## 
## REML criterion at convergence: 690.8
## 
## Scaled residuals: 
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -5.2159 -0.5535 -0.0943  0.4332  4.4438 
## 
## Random effects:
##  Groups   Name                Variance Std.Dev. Corr                   
##  SpEv     (Intercept)         0.22964  0.4792                          
##           ordered(distance).L 1.18409  1.0882   -0.99                  
##           ordered(distance).Q 0.26944  0.5191    0.95 -0.98            
##           ordered(distance).C 0.04173  0.2043   -0.98  0.99 -0.99      
##           ordered(distance)^4 0.04360  0.2088   -0.28  0.38 -0.57  0.45
##  Residual                     0.41196  0.6418                          
## Number of obs: 334, groups:  SpEv, 6
## 
## Fixed effects:
##                     Estimate Std. Error t value
## (Intercept)           1.2038     0.1991   6.045
## ordered(distance).L  -1.9538     0.4528  -4.314
## ordered(distance).Q   0.8012     0.2268   3.533
## ordered(distance).C  -0.2747     0.1212  -2.267
## ordered(distance)^4   0.1533     0.1132   1.355
## 
## Correlation of Fixed Effects:
##             (Intr) or().L or().Q or().C
## ordrd(ds).L -0.962                     
## ordrd(ds).Q  0.882 -0.900              
## ordrd(ds).C -0.660  0.672 -0.658       
## ordrd(ds)^4 -0.234  0.281 -0.335  0.190
## convergence code: 0
## boundary (singular) fit: see ?isSingular

    The fixed effects give us the mean number of lesions per plant at distance zero (intercept) and this is significantly different from zero. We can also see the mean number of lesions decreases as distance from the focus increases.

    From here we should continue with a generalised additive model (GAM), which can handle non-linear terms better than a linear model with polynomials.
